questions.question: If you had practiced every day, you …………………………
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had …………………………. I could buy a car.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adjective it goes before the noun it modifies.

questions.question: He was …………………………… to lend me 100 dollars.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adverb, it goes after the adjective or adverb modified by it.

questions.question: Don’t come tomorrow. I would rather you ………………………….. on Sunday.
questions.description: After would rather we use a past tense with a present or future meaning.

questions.question: Nothing happened, …………………………..?
questions.description: In question tags, we use it to refer to nothing.

questions.question: …………………………… the film, I don’t want to read the book.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses we get: I have seen the film. I don’t want to read the book.
We can combine them using having seen.

questions.question: Everything is all right, …………………………?
questions.description: In question tags we use it to refer to everything.

questions.question: You had better …………………………. saying thank-you for things.
questions.description: We use infinitive without to after ‘had better’.

questions.question: When we were kids, my uncle ……………………………. us out on his bike all round the countryside.
questions.description: Would and used to can both be used to talk about habitual behaviour in the past.

questions.question: You were foolish to try climbing up there. You ……………………………. yourself.
questions.description: Could have + past participle can be used to say that something was possible but did not happen.

questions.question: I am not accustomed to ………………………… personal information to strangers.
questions.description: After accustomed to we can use an -ing from or an infinitive without much difference of meaning.

questions.question: I slowly began ……………………………. what she was going through.
questions.description: The stative verb understand is usually used in the infinitive form.
